course.subject: LIFS
course.name: Biochemistry II
course.description: Principles of bioenergetics and cellular structures; glycolysis, citric acid cycle, electron transport, oxidative phosphorylation and chemiosmosis; carbohydrate, lipid, amino acid and nucleotide metabolism; photosynthesis and nitrogen fixation.

reviews.author: Paolo
reviews.title: Not as hard as one might think...
reviews.comment_content:
CH1: Chemical Logic and Introduction to metabolism
CH2: Glycolysis
CH3: Krebs Cycle (aka. Citric Cycle or TCA Cycle)
CH4: Oxidative Phosphorylation and Oxygen
CH5: Pentose Phosphate Pathway
CH6: Carbohydrate Metabolism
•CH6.a: Gluconeogenesis
•CH6.b: Glycogen Metabolism

CH7: Lipid Metabolism
•CH7.a: Fatty Acid Biosynthesis and Oxidation
•CH7.b: Membrane Lipids, Sphingolipids, Sphingolipids, Steroids, Isoprenoids, and Eicosanoid
CH8: Metabolism of Nitrogenous Compounds
CH9: Nucleotide Metabolism
CH10: Integration of Metabolism
CH11: Extracellular Chemical Signal

Chapter 1 - 6 = Exam I (midterm)
Chapter 7 - 11 = Exam II (final)
Assignment = 300 word Essay on any topic related to the syllabus

The Exams are all multiple choice + short answer questions. Though Professor Robert changed the Exam II format to True or False, so im not sure if he will stick to this in the future. But regardless they do not affect the difficulty too much.

Professor Robert will almost all the time test you on information that was covered in the lecture powerpoint ONLY.

Often times, he will discuss the medical issues related to each chapters. Thats mainly to aid you on your essay writing, as the role of the essay is to see how well you can discuss about what you learn form each chapter.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Robert's teaching is excellent. IDK what exactly to say. I quite enjoy his lectures.
He talks not too fast or not too slow.
He teaches with enthusiasm.
He is funny and makes jokes often.
He does his best to relate ecah chapter to our everyday life.

Though occasionally, he spends too much time explaining some slides.

Nevertheless, his lectures will make you understand the powerpoints better. I'd recommend you to attend the lectures, and if you miss his lectures, he uploads recorded lectures for you to play.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading of examinations are dependent on the normal distribution curve. Professor Robert hands out the grades very well, i believe 1 SD is enough for at least A-.

For Exam I:
mean = 59.05
SD = 19
my marks = 79.5 (just 1 SD above mean)

not sure about my Exam II or my essay marks, but i got a solid A in the end.
reviews.comment_workload:
I'd say the workload is light, but thats mainly because im good at memorising facts, not to brag or anything. And yes, there are quite a lot of memorising for this course.

You don't have to know the chemical formulae of each reactants and products, but you have to at least know their name, and the chemical logic for each reactions.

You'll also have to know the enzymes that are the regulation points for each metabolic processes. You'll learn the ways of regulation in class, but there are substrates that regulate enzyme activity which are called allosteric effectors. Each regulatory enzymes have unique allosteric effectors, so you'll have to remember them all.

As scary as this may seem, however they are not that difficult to understand. And if you understand them, these will make sense to you, and this will make memorisation less difficult.

My advise to you is to NEVER leave your revision to the last minute. Allocate at least 2 weeks to review all your notes.

Another advise is to study ACTIVELY, not passively. Since you will be dealing with lots of facts, you have to make sure it stays in your long term memory. How to do this is to KEEP testing yourself. After making your summary notes, divided into sections, cover a section and try to recall all the key points there.
Any point you fail to recall, take note of it so the next time you test yourself again, you're more likely to remember it.

As for the 300 word Essay, its a piece of cake as long as you understand the necessary chapters, and you have at least 2 weeks to complete it.

reviews.comment_content:
The main topics covered include:

1. Glycolysis
2. Tricarboxylic Acid Cycle
3. Oxidative Phosphorylation
4. Pentose Phosphate Pathway
5. Gluconeogenesis
6. Glycogenesis & Glycogenolysis
=== Exam 1 ===

7. Lipogenesis & Lipolysis
8. Amino Acid Metabolism
9. Nucleotide Metabolism
10. Basic Cell Signalling
=== Exam 2 ===


The examinations are not cumulative, but some questions in Exam 2 would require knowledge from Exam 1. Hence, it would better if you can review some key concepts regarding carbohydrate metabolism prior to Exam 2. The contents are not too difficult to understand per se, but it definitely takes time to remember all the individual biochemical processes.

I personally do not find the course contents interesting, nor do I consider them particularly “useful” for future studies, unless you are deeply captivated by metabolic systems.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I did not attend any of the lectures after the first 2. However, since all lecture videos are provided, I did watch most of them before the examinations.

Like most other comments, I think Professor Ko’s explanations are clear, but honestly too slow – so slow that you would have already forgotten what the last point was about upon hearing the next. Whilst this would be OK for other courses where contents between each segment may not be too closely linked, it is definitely a hurdle for this specific course, since it requires students to understand a metabolic pathway holistically from its constituent reactions.

Since Professor Ko spoke very slowly, watching the lecture videos at 2-times speed is tolerable.

Not sure about the overall grading, so I will put a “B” here.

I would suggest putting some efforts into the essay even though it only contributes 10% towards the course grade. One reason for this is that an acquaintance of mine, who initially ranked highly in class, experienced a significant drop in rank due to subpar essay scores. I presume Professor Ko would be more thrilled to mark essay topics that interest him, or are related to his field of research.

P.S. The topic I wrote was not taught in class. You can basically write whatever you like as long as it is related to the course content (at least for this year), in addition to the topics provided.
reviews.comment_workload:
There is not much actual workload aside from the 300-word essay, which can be finished within a few hours.

As for the revision, looking through all metabolic pathways at once is definitely intimidating, but since Professor Ko would not ask about the exact mechanistic details of each biochemical reaction, rote memorisation is not that necessary, unlike some other courses (*cough* Organic Chemistry I and II *cough*).

Still, you would need to remember the names of important enzymes, allosteric effectors, and covalent modifications. If you are taking this course together or after LIFS 2040, you should be familiar with most of these regulatory mechanisms (e.g., phosphorylation and dephosphorylation). Particularly, most of the pathways learnt in this course are actually regulated by feedback controls, so additional memorisation of allosteric effectors is usually not necessary as long as you know what the downstream products are.

I would suggest spending around a week of time reviewing the lecture videos, and piecing all individual reactions together into a single summary afterwards for easier revision. Since learning how individual metabolic pathways cooperate to yield specific physiological responses is the ultimate goal of this course, I believe making a concise overall summary of all biochemical reactions taught would help.

reviews.comment_workload:
This course covers all sorts of biochemical pathways. That means you have whole sets of enzymes, substrates, cofactors, etc. to recite.

You need to revise it daily or you'll end up forgetting things as the course covers so many things. I suggest that if you are not good at memorizing things and not diligent enough, don't take this course. It is quite arduous to spend a lot of time understanding and remembering things.

Of course, this is a science course, so requires an understanding of concepts as well but you need to remember many things to do well in this course.

reviews.author: ym7135
reviews.comment_content:
I would say this course has a lot more content than a lot of Life Science courses, but it is definitely the highlight for anyone doing the BCB Major. In my semester the order of topics were:
1) Energetics and basics of biochemistry
2) Glycolysis
3) Citric Acid Cycle
4) ETC
5) Pentose Phosphate Pathway
6) Gluconeogenesis and Glycogen metabolism
7) Lipid metabolism
8) Nitrogenous compounds
9) Nucleotide metabolism
10) Integration of metabolism
11) Extracellular regulation (aka signalling)

Each topic can go in a lot of depth, but what is good about this course is that you ONLY focus on what the professor has mentioned in the lecture (there is NOTHING in the exam which requires outside reading), and definitely focus on what the professor keeps emphasising and repeating.
reviews.comment_teaching:
A majority of the course was taught by Robert Ko (except lipid metabolism), and honestly one of the best professors in Life Science. He teaches with a lot of enthusiasm and passion, explains the powerpoint in great detail, and he relates a lot of the knowledge to a wider perspective like weight loss, exercise, and diseases. The guest professor for lipid metabolism is quite similar, but he only teaches 3 lectures.

Exam-wise, whatever both professors mention in class is more than enough for exam revision, so I suggest reviewing all the lectures either by being present or watching it in Canvas. If they repeat certain concepts a couple of times in class this concept is for sure going to be examined.
reviews.comment_grading:
There are two exams (not really classified mid term and final), both being 45%, the first one covers 1) - 6) from above, the second exam is the rest (but 7) - 11) highly depends on 1) - 6) so I do suggest going over it briefly for Exam II).

Each exam is about 60% MCQ (regular), 20% with the more than one answered MCQ and 20% with essay questions. But very honestly the exams are SIMPLE QUESTIONS TO VERY COMPLEX CONCEPTS - basically if you understand and memorize the lecture materials properly the questions are quite simple.

There is also a 300 Word Assignment worth 10%, you choose your topic from a list of 6-7 assigned to the class. This is given towards the end.
reviews.comment_workload:
This course is mainly understanding the concepts and preparing for exams; there are a lot of materials to go over.

If you want to be time effective and get a good grade, my biggest advice is don't read the textbook - it goes over too much that is not required, a lot of stuff that is required is not present in textbook. Take detailed notes from the lecture and study that.

The assignment will take no longer than a day to research and complete.

45% Exam I
45% Exam 2
10% Short Essay

The essays will be given at the end of the course when you are done with the syllabus, just make sure to choose the right topic.

reviews.author: Chris K
reviews.title: Just some info about this course
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Ko teaches with passion and interest, so he sometimes talks some topics that are not included in the syllabus or exam. But he tells the students that which type of information will not be on the exam which is very helpful.
His powerpoints are very concise and short with quite a lot of diagrams, so it is recommended to watch the lecture video or attend the lecture. Also, professor asks students to understand not memorize, but personally I think it requires memorization. It is impossible to memorize the whole metabolism of molecules, but some names are important in the exam.
His accents are sometimes quite hard to understand but acceptable. He uploaded all the lectures in my semester, but understanding what professor is saying through the video is harder than actually going to the lecture due to background noise.
reviews.comment_grading: I personally think the exam itself is not that hard, but quite confusing with a lot of questions. Exams consist of both MC and short answer questions, but I personally found hard to get full marks in the short answer questions. It you actually spend some time studying this course, it is quite easy to get within mean+-sd range.
reviews.comment_workload:
The grading is based on one essay and two exams. The length of the essay is only 300 words, so it is not that big of a deal.
For exams, there are a lot of metabolism for different substances like carbohydraets, proteins etc... I think finiding out the keypoint or crucial info is very important for this course because it is impossible to memorize everything.
Overall, workload for this course is mainly preparation for exams.

reviews.comment_content: The course content was quite tricky, the pathways are super detailed and can take a really long time to memorize. They are topics you might have briefly touched upon prior to the course but can expect to learn in much more detail in this course.

reviews.comment_workload: There is barely any workload. The only assignment is to write a 300-word short essay based on a topic in biochemistry, which is due at the end of the semester. Other than that, only revision for midterm and finals is required.

reviews.comment_teaching:
Honestly I don't like Robert KO's teaching style... For me, he speaks too slowly that makes me sleepy and hard to concentrate, and his explanation of the slides doesn't make the structure and relationship between different parts very clear. To have a more systematic point of view, I would recommend reading the textbook. However, as the opposite extreme, the textbook contains way too many details, which causes difficulty in grasping the key points. Therefore, a combined approach would be to attend the lecture and get a brief idea about what you should know, read the textbook to understand it better, and return to the concise slides before exams.
There are nonetheless some good things about his teaching. He usually combines the abstract pathways with some daily life experience, which helps with understanding the concepts. He also provides practice questions and tutorial questions, which is helpful for revision before the exams. However, some of the things covered in tutorial questions seem to be not appearing in the lecture notes, which is a bit confusing.
reviews.comment_grading:
I think this course is known for relatively good grades (but maybe not that good as biochemistry I? not sure...)
45% midterm (first half)
45% final (non-cumulative)
10% short essay with a topic on metabolism-related issues in lifestyle, health, and diseases (300 words)
The topic of the short essay is briefly covered in class, but some extra reading may be needed.
The exam is composed of MCs that are 1 point each, MC that are 2 points each, and some T/F statements that are 1 point each. Some of the exam questions is very similar or the same as the review questions.
Me:
midterm: 66/69, Mean: 43.07, SD: 12.30, High: 69
final: 74/89? (forgot the full mark) Mean: 7.02, SD: 0.90
short essay: 9/10, Mean: 7.02, SD: 0.90
A+
reviews.comment_workload: It's better to start the revision 1 week before the exam, as there are quite some reactions and pathways to remember. You don't need to remember the chemical reaction formula, but you need to know the flow of the pathway, its purpose and function, the substrate, product, some important enzyme, regulatory point, allosteric regulators, etc. Familiarizing yourself with the contents by attending the lectures and reading the textbook may be good. Understanding a bit of the underlying chemistry mechanism may help with your memorization. It's also useful to write and draw the pathways down in your own way and making comparisons. I would say the workload is not too high.
